events.target_title: Opacity, Strange ... In Layer Group
FTBFS: ./autogen.sh: '../../config.rpath' not found

note.body:
I got on gitlab! Here's what I posted to the bugzilla while I was having trouble getting on gitlab:

I figured out why it failed for me and not you!

To reproduce:

git clone ...gegl

cd gegl

touch ../../install-sh

./autogen.sh



It seems that autotools finds that, and expects other files to be there too.

Looks like this is a documented "feature" of automake though:

https://www.gnu.org/software/automake/manual/automake.html#index-AC_005fCONFIG_005fAUX_005fDIR-1 (section about AC_CONFIG_AUX_DIR)


I ran afoul of this by cloning gimp, then in a subdirectory, cloning gegl and babl.

I'm not sure what if anything should be done about this. Some projects ship install-sh in the git repo, I don't know if this is standard/recommended though.

note.body: Debian doesn't like to include sbin directories by default in the user PATH, preferring to use sudoers to add all (s)bin path. The interesting thing however is that Disks doesn't seem to ask for root permissions before trying to format the disk. BTW, this behavior isn't exclusive to Debian, as [Fedora uses it too](https://unix.stackexchange.com/a/8652/41104).

events.target_title: Transforming a layer doesn't properly transform its mask

note.body:
Hi @ell, gimp 2.10.10-1 here on Arch Linux. The two sets of tests/observations in #2633 no longer occur; the problem appears fixed.

@DaFeBa, could it be you have the mask selected rather than the layer? There are two thumbnails for each layer with a mask.  If the left one is selected then transformations affect the layer and its mask, if the right one is selected then the transformation affects only the mask. Which one is selected is shown by a thick outline around the thumbnail.

note.body:
A screenshot so searchers can confirm this is their problem. The boxes are single-width, but given a wide spacing.  The cursor is also wide.

![pango-386-wide-boxes-for-bitmap-fonts](/uploads/999a3473d49947c3db581f58b0206cc7/pango-386-wide-boxes-for-bitmap-fonts.png)

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
The blog post says

>  Using Harfbuzz for font loading means that we will lose support for bitmap and type1 fonts. We think this is an acceptable trade-off, but others might disagree. Note that Harfbuzz does support loading bitmap-only OpenType fonts.

Can someone that knows confirm my guess that all bitmap fonts can be left as identical bitmaps in an OpenType format using FontForge's https://fontforge.github.io/generate.html ?  Is there a technical or legal reason font packagers haven't switched to shipping bitmaps in this newer format?  Or just lack of need when everything was working just fine?

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
So I've wasted quite a few hours now chasing this around.  There's the option of getting upstream font creators to ship OpenType bitmap formats because Harfbuzz is our only hope.  That's multiple parties: GNU BDF Unifont, X.Org, ...  And if they all played ball then the distro packagers would have to pass those changes onto their users.

That won't help all those that do graphics with gimp, etc., and have accumulated a large collection of personal bitmap fonts over the years that now draw as boxes.  Presumably, they'd all have to discover the problem, and find not-yet-written clear instructions for how to easily convert their personal collection, including going forwards since many font repositories on the web ship bitmaps.

Or, is there any chance Harfbuzz can be taught to load BDF, etc., bitmaps fonts, probably converting them on the fly as if they were the OpenType bitmap format?  That would centralise the effort, and minimise it, saving many people's time from discovering the issue to working around it.  I see requests for FON support, etc., in the past.  That was reasonably turned down, but perhaps now times have changed, i.e. Pango has dumped responsibility on Harfbuzz.

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body: Hi Matthias, I wasn't assuming ill intent; sorry if it came across that way.  BTW, thanks for retrospectively updating 1.44's NEWS to make clear that's the release that dropped Type 1 and bitmap support; it helps when searching for what's happened and why.

As a side note with GTK3 one issue that will crop up is scrollbar overlays that some distributions use can cause issues with some buttons in the dock not being easily accessible. You might want to to disable overlays in GIMP because of that issue.

events.target_title: Add gnome-kra-ora-thumbnailer to Flatpak
provide thumbnailing support for KRA and ORA files
provide thumbnailing support for KRA and ORA files

note.body:
@csoriano Thanks for the prompt response.
I'll try to ask the community, but I think the chance of getting the support are close to zero.
I have added a bug report to the archived project that i linked too, I hope someone picks it up , even then it may not get into the repos unless someone packages it, so the barriers to solve this are higher than I thought.

Any idea how jpg png videos get thumbnails? Are they third party too? If there is a repo for those, I will try to ask the devs of thos thumbnailers to may be give some consideration to these format also.

events.target_title: provide thumbnailing support for KRA and ORA files

note.body:
I am asking on r/gnome if anybody is interested in reviving this archived gnome repo
https://gitlab.gnome.org/Archive/gnome-kra-ora-thumbnailer

If these are revived then may be I would get a chance to ask the distros to package this.

events.target_title: Add gnome-kra-ora-thumbnailer to Flatpak

note.body:
I apologise to barge in the discussion here, I wish to also bring this (prior and possibly duplicate issue) discussion and issue to everyone's notice here - https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/585 . It might help in considering what is already discussed and may be add to this discussion.

note.body:
Hi Curtis,

Here's patch v1 to fix this issue.
(Patch is attached so for the moment we are still using our old work
flow in gitlab issues, just like we did in bugzilla).

Successfully tested on:
1) CentOS 6 with lvm 2.02.143 which does not require --yes to be uses
   with 'lvm pvresize --setphysicalvolumesize', but obviously allows it
   to be used.
   LVM2 PV shrink works with --yes added.
2) CentOS 7 with lvm2 2.02.177 which does require --yes to be used.
   Confirmed broken without this patch and fixed with this patch.
3) Fedora 28 with lvm2 2.02.177.
   Confirmed broken without this patch and fixed with this patch.

Thanks,
Mike
[gparted-1-pvresize-yes-flag-v1.patch](/uploads/b78eb57dd7518bb6d634906666ff0eba/gparted-1-pvresize-yes-flag-v1.patch)

events.target_title: Can't shrink LVM partition due to pvresize prompt

note.body:
Testing details again, but this time with formatting.  (Still getting use to gitlab issues).

1.  CentOS 6 with lvm 2.02.143 which does not require --yes to be uses with 'lvm pvresize --setphysicalvolumesize', but obviously allows it to be used.  LVM2 PV shrink works with --yes added.
2.  CentOS 7 with lvm2 2.02.177 which does require --yes to be used.  Confirmed broken without this patch and fixed with this patch.
3.  Fedora 28 with lvm2 2.02.177.  Confirmed broken without this patch and fixed with this patch.

events.target_title: Can't shrink LVM partition due to pvresize prompt

note.body:
From a quick look at the pvresize code [1][2] there are 2 cases when it
prompts questions.
1.  When the size of the PV is set larger than the size of the
    containing partition.  (Corruption guaranteed).  When GParted is
    growing an LVM2 PV it does't specifiy the size or the --yes option
    so will never encounter this question.
2.  when the size of the PV is set less than the size of the containing
    partition.  This case is the cause of this issue.

[1] tools/resize.c  
    https://sourceware.org/git/?p=lvm2.git;a=blob;f=tools/pvresize.c;h=e951f11f6739a487cb2865fcda65ec8048b4e344;hb=HEAD

[2] lib/metadata/pv_manip.c:pv_resize_single()  
    https://sourceware.org/git/?p=lvm2.git;a=blob;f=lib/metadata/pv_manip.c;h=5fd80a2ceca36e0a14b306b4eac442f4f3d15aa1;hb=HEAD#l614

So:
1.  At the moment lvm pvresize doesn't appear to have any other cases
    that could prompt.
2.  The proposed patch only adds auto answer yes when shrinking a PV.
3.  Given that GParted is using the command line interface there doesn't
    appear to be any alternative.  (Option -qq only provides auto answer
    no).
4.  GParted is taking responsibility for performing the actions and
    therefore using the externally run commands correctly in each
    situation.  It does similar things by auto answering yes or using
    force options for various other commands.  I don't see this as any
    different.  Examples of other commands where GParted uses force or
    auto answer yes:
    *   Removing an LVM2 PV
    *   Labelling an NTFS
    *   Resizing an NTFS
    *   Making a reiser4 file system
    *   File system checking reiser4
    *   File system checking reiserfs
    *   Resizing a reiserfs file system

events.target_title: Upload HW cursor sprite on-demand

note.body:
I just upgraded from Fedora 27 (using Xorg) to Fedora 28 (which switched back to Wayland). Gnome was unusable: libinput logged many errors about lag between 30 and 300 ms, gnome-shell also logged warnings about latency, and Firefox was stuck between 500 and 2000 ms when I closed a tab.

@jadahl told me about this issue. My Lenovo P50 has two GPUs: Intel and nVidia. When I plugged a second output (television by HDMI) to get an extended deskop, the problem is gone.

Then @jadahl produced a RPM for my Fedora and I can now confirm that the problem is gone even without external monitor (only the one included in my laptop).

Gnome was unusable with the GPU, and now I'm unable to notice any latency issue and all latency warnings in logs are also gone. Good!

events.target_title: No notifications dot next to date/time
No notifications dot next to date/time

note.body:
> A notification is marked as read when [...] it has been shown as banner

That doesn't make much sense to me, personally. If it's been shown as a banner, all that means is that it came across the screen. If I'm looking at another screen, or looking away from my computer, or am physically away from my computer, a banner that showed is certainly not "read", and I personally wouldn't expect it to be marked as such.

> The expected behavior there is that the notification doesn't time out while you are away, and greets you when you get back

Two questions about this: 

1.) This doesn't happen for any of the apps I've used, as far as I can tel. All notifications popup, dismiss shortly there after, and don't leave a dot, so if I'm not lucky enough to see the notification, I miss it.

2.) You say the notification shouldn't time out "while [I'm] away". How does it know? What determines if a notification stays on screen or if it dismisses a couple of seconds after showing up (which all mine seem to do)? I take it from this quote:

> maybe you are seeing a bug in the code that monitors user activity

That there's some code that determines if a user is active or not. That's possible, if what I'm experiencing isn't expected. I'm curious what determines that. If I'm typing away, then take 10 seconds to close my eyes and stretch, it's possible that in those 10 seconds a notification has come and gone, and not left a dot or any sort of indicator for me to see. I assume that 10 seconds of inactivity would not be enough to trigger whatever user activity monitoring code you're referring to.

So, the questions become: 

1.) How do I get a more persistent, reliable indicator of notifications? 

2.) Am I experiencing and bug, and how can I find out or test for it?

3.) Does the gnome shell team like or agree with my ideas for improvement of the dot indicator, and might they be implemented?

[Texttool] Support for East Asian vertical text writing style

note.body:
The OP said some scripts can do that, I think he or she meant rearranging text in order to make them look like vertical layout text. However, the rearrangement approach is not really correct, and just produces mistaken results.

First, line heights and horizontal advantages for characters are completely two different concepts; second, modern font formats also have other native vertical layout information besides horizontal advantages, such as how to substitute vertical punctuation glyphs for horizontal punctuation glyphs, etc. So using scripts is really a mistaken approach.

So no scripts can really implement this feature, native support for vertical layout text is necessary.

GZlibCompressor over GSocketConnection sends extra bytes on close

note.body:
Sorry for the late reply, I've been of a conference w/o access to my development box…

> I haven’t read through the deflate specification, but I assume they indicate the end of the stream.

Maybe, I didn't check either…  But actually this isn't the point here (see below).

> So to ensure those two bytes are sent when you want them to be, you should explicitly close the output stream

Actually, I _don't_ want the extra two bytes being sent when I shut down the connection!

> The server will need to expect those two extra bytes and not immediately close the connection[…]

The example simulates a _very_ simplified data flow of a compressed IMAP connection.  [RFC 4978](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4978) defines only the parameters for compression and the actions to start the compressed connection, but not how it shall be shut down (somewhat similar to STARTTLS, which doesn't specify a way to _end_ encryption either).  Thus, IMO the shutdown sequence as specified in [RFC 3501, Sect. 3.4](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3501#section-3.4) applies which clearly states that the server shall reply with IMAP messages after receiving the LOGOUT command and then just close the connection.

IOW, in order to create a standard-compliant client, GIO must be able to suppress the two extra bytes.

> Wrt the issue with #define `SIM_ERROR 0`, I can’t reproduce the critical warning.

The critical occurs only when the connection is first encrypted and then compressed (as required by RFC 4978).  As it is somewhat cumbersome to look into an encrypted connection's pcap, I omitted this layer.  Sorry for the confusion!

I attach a new test case which both encrypts and compresses the connection which is closer to the real-world use case: run `./echoserver.py` in one terminal and in a second
1.  `./test-comp 0`: the two extra bytes are _not_ transmitted, but the “CRITICAL” occurs;
2.  `./test-comp 1`: the two extra bytes, no critical

similar to the unencrypted case.

Conclusion: at the moment, I have the choice between an implementation violating RFC 3501, or one which throws a CRITICAL…
[testcase2.zip](/uploads/f8070cc08314fc417c89595c2a361a38/testcase2.zip)

> GNOME has decided that application menus, shown in the top bar of the GNOME desktop, are a bad idea.

Well, this has always been an inferior rip-off of the MacOS GUI…  While it's perfect there, I agree that dropping it for Gnome (and others, I use XFCE) is a good idea.

The code from the branch looks nice.  However, maybe it's a good moment to re-organise some of the menus?  I didn't look into the HIG, but here are some ideas:
* the File menu is a little crowded.  What about
  * move the Preferences sub-menu either to a new top-level menu bar item, or to Edit (like Firefox)
  * likewise, Help (the contents is outdated, btw…) and About to a new Help top-level menu bar item (Help -> Manual and Help -> About)

> The suggested top-level `Help` menu has items `Contents` and `About`.

Ah!  Exactly what I was thinking about…

So you actually mean “[…] `File → Empty trash` […] just above `Quit`”, do you?
> I'm not sure about duplicating `File → New → Message` as `Message → New…` (or were you suggesting moving it?).

My suggestion is to move the item.  In the message menu, we have all the options to compose a new message from an _existing_ one (Forward, Reply, …).  Therefore, my feeling is that `New…` would suit better there.
> If we did, should we do the same for the File → New → xx Mailbox items?

Good question.  We could argue that a new mailbox (at least a local one) does actually create a file or folder, thus `File` is the proper place.  But that might be too technical.  Hmmm…

> The HIG also requires a `Go` menu […]

Also a good idea!  The `Mailbox` menu is crowded, too, and somewhat confused IMHO – e.g. I would group `Expunge…` and `Remove Duplicates` together, the two filter-related entries, …

(enhancement) remember to allow "Download images" for a given sender

note.body:
I understand the purpose of your request, but I wonder if this is a *really* good idea, to be honest…

In general, HTML messages should be considered dangerous.  HTML can be used for various attacks, as has been demonstrated by [EFail](https://efail.de/), or recently by [Johnny you are fired](https://github.com/RUB-NDS/Johnny-You-Are-Fired).  Spoofing sender addresses is trivial and a common practice used in  (mal-)spam campaigns.  And, no, [DKIM does not help](https://noxxi.de/research/breaking-dkim-on-purpose-and-by-chance.html)!  Thus, I think using this option would be somewhat risky.

The only safe solution IMHO would be an option to download images from OpenPGP or S/MIME signed message parts **only**, based upon the fingerprint (not the UID!) of the key used.  However, I don't think this is typical use case of (commercial – who else would add links to external material?) HTML messages…

note.body:
I had a look at the Send Account Override options after having this bug
repeatedly occur for one particular email recipient, and added them to
see if that fixed it. I don't send emails to them often but it hasn't
occurred since then—prior to adding the override it happened regularly,
even on replying to an email they sent. So that may have fixed it for
this particular recipient? I don't have any other overrides set up.

I've also had it happen a couple of times when replying to mailing
lists, and only known after the event because the mailing list has sent
an automated delivery failure notice as my "Default" account isn't used
for those lists. In those cases I've replied to a posting on the
mailing list and the email has bounced straight away.

The only pattern I can think of is that the issue only occurs when
sending from the secondary Google account, and Evolution sends it from
the primary Google account instead. I haven't had it get confused
between the Exchange account and a Google account. One thing I have
noticed (and I'm not sure if this is related or a separate issue) is
that Evolution often hangs while trying to send an email from the
Google accounts because it loses the connection to the SMTP server.
It'll pop up with a notification saying it can't send the email,
offering to save as a draft, or save to outbox, or cancel, and will
only resend successfully if I save to outbox, go offline, and then go
online again and click Send/Receive. Ironically enough, Evolution did exactly that while replying to this:![send-mail-fail](/uploads/c3e464bb9b0b0f64d6747645def0a91f/send-mail-fail.png)

Given that I don't send many emails in general, I think it'll be
difficult to figure out what's going on if nobody else has encountered
something similar. I'll keep track of when this occurs, and in the
meantime I suspect the best you can do is flag this as "Needs More
Information"; if I notice a pattern I'll add another comment with
updated information.

note.body:
The recapitulation is correct.

Please, for the following assume:
- "file" refers to "~/Desktop/test"
- "with content" means a single letter in file is sufficient
  

I would have expected that `thunar` and `nautilus` have the same behaviour. But the strange situation is:
- `nautilus` can copy/cut-paste file (with or without content) to either home directory location


On the other hand with `thunar` this works:
- copy/cut empty file and paste it in either homedirectory path
- copy/cut file with content and paste it into /mount2/USER

But this fails:
- copy/cut file with content and paste it into /mount1/USER  
The error message is "The destination is read-only."

events.target_title: symlink on read-only NFS share redirects homedirectory -- prevents thunar to paste to homedirectory

note.body:
I am sorry for late reply.

`/mount1/name` is the homedirectory. But it is a symlink to `/mount2/name`, to which the user can write.
We do not want to use `mount --bind /mount2/name /mount1/name`.
We are using the symlink solution for more than 12 years with Fedora and CentOS.


`~` is resolved to `/mount1/name` for user `name`.
With "homedirectory path" in "... either homedirectory path" I mean both `/mount1/name` and `/mount2/name`.
  
  
### Examples with concrete paths:
````
$ cd ; pwd
/mount1/name
$ touch Desktop/empty
$ echo "a" > Desktop/content
````
Results of copying files from `/mount1/name/Desktop` to `/mount1/name` with `thunar`:
* content  # fails; I do not get why this fails, but everything else works
* empty  # works

Results of cut-pasting files from `/mount1/name/Desktop` to `/mount1/name` with `thunar`:
* content  # works
* empty  # works

Results of cut-pasting as well as copying files from `/mount2/name/Desktop` to `/mount2/name` with `thunar`:
* content  # works
* empty  # works



Output of these commands is empty and they work:
````
$ cd ; pwd
/mount1/name  # same results when cd'ing to /mount2/name
$ gio copy Desktop/empty .
$ gio copy Desktop/content .
$ gio move Desktop/empty .
$ gio move Desktop/content .
````

note.body:
@Meuret Uhm... You must be seeing a different bug then?!?
Commit 2ce63a86ba689aa41eb47409c889c469497478b0 is not part of GTK+ 3.22.30. This commit added a call to `gdk_window_x11_set_background` after this line (link goes to the file in the 3.22.30 release): https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/2e7ac262be15fb402c4103d28533c6c6d955bf65/gdk/x11/gdkwindow-x11.c#L1148

At least Arch does not apply any patches to GTK+ 3.22.30. For Manjaro, I failed to find the PKGBUILD, but their [lib32-gtk3-classic](https://gitlab.manjaro.org/packages/multilib/lib32-gtk3-classic/blob/master/PKGBUILD) is based on something called gtk3-mushrooms. The author of gtk3-mushrooms said that he took some patches from GTK+ git that cause this: https://github.com/awesomeWM/awesome/issues/2279#issuecomment-394077361

events.target_title: Race during window setup when creating windows for embedding

note.body:
Some more technical details:

- Gtk creates the window-to-be-embedded directly inside of the target parent window.
- Tabbed starts working when it gets a CreateNotify.

The problem now is that Gtk creates its window with an empty event mask and only asks for events later. Thus, if tabbed is fast enough, Gtk's window can be mapped before Gtk asks for MapNotify events. This results in the bug that @dset0x is seeing, i.e. Gtk creating a window but not rendering it.

Part of the problem is that Tabbed ignores the _XEMBED_INFO property, but per the Xembed spec, it is actually Gtk that does something wrong here, because the spec says that the window should be created and set up "elsewhere" and then reparented into the "target parent".

Some more of my analysis can be found here: https://github.com/awesomeWM/awesome/issues/2385#issuecomment-419887367
This also contains two patches to Gtk. One adds a `sleep(1)` so that tabbed always wins the race, making the problem easier to reproduce. The second patch fixes this by creating the Gtk window with the right event mask, thus eliminating the race.

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
It was [suggested above](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/443#note_126453) that @antoniof's proposal might violate Canonical's policies.

> For Canonical, https://wiki.ubuntu.com/SecurityTeam/Policies which states:
> > The error message when trying ___to open___ an executable file must:
> > - explain why this may be a dangerous file
> > - not give the option of launching it anyway

However, that policy only applies when try to ___open___ an executable file, not when trying to ___run___ it. When I double-click an executable file I want run it, not open it, hence this proposal is OK.  ;)

Seriously though, @antoniof's original proposal was to add a "Run as Program" option to the context menu, so this can hardly be seen as trying to "open" the program.

events.target_title: general: Don't allow launching binaries or programs in general

note.body: @suckybell, that's not a bad idea and, in fact, we'd love to be able to do exactly that for AppImages.  However, there is still the case where you email a script to your computer-illiterate friend and they need to be able to just run it, without any kind of "installation".

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
@Ads20000, I respectfully disagree. I would be interested to hear what the people who wrote that policy have to say, but it clearly says "trying to open" and not "trying to run". A text script that doesn't have the executable bit set is not an executable.

Besides, @antoniof's proposal does not give the option to "run the program anyway"; it gives the option to apply the executable bit. Only *then* is the user able to click the button to run the program, and this is consistent with Ubuntu's policy [Execute-permission bit required](https://wiki.ubuntu.com/SecurityTeam/Policies#Execute-Permission_Bit_Required).

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body: (Just thought I'd point out that the current double-click message "There is no application installed for executable files" violates Canonical's policy.)

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
It is reasonably clear to me that Canonical's policy is only there to stop users falling for the `my_cat.jpg.exe` attack where 'opening' (what appears to be) a regular file actually runs a program. I don't think the policy was intended to stop users from running legitimate programs that the user *knows* are programs (though, of course, that is the effect it inevitably has).

As @Ads20000 [pointed out](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/443#note_224462), the line about "not allowing users to run it anyway" has been around since 2009, so I think it is extremely unlikely that this policy was intended as a way of locking people in to a snap-only future.

---

To protect users from `my_cat.jpg.exe`, all that is really needed is a way to warn users that the file they clicked on is a program and not simply a regular file. The warning needs to be given in such a way that the user cannot accidentally/automatically click "proceed" without first having read and understood the dialog message (hence the "not run it anyway" stipulation).

I think @antoniof's original proposal meets these requirements. The user has to click a checkbox, which applies the executable bit, before they can click "run". The dialog itself is only accessible by right-clicking on the file and choosing "Run program", so the user would only choose it if they *already knew it was a program* and not a regular file. This provides a level of protection that is more than adequate to thwart `my_cat.jpg.exe` and similar attacks.

---

The remaining question is what to do when the user double-clicks on the file, or uses right-click "Open" instead of right-click "Run". Shell scripts can simply be opened in a text editor, but what about ELF files and other binary executables? We can't just ignore the user's command, or present the cryptic message "no application installed for executable files".

In fact, Ubuntu's policy makes it quite clear what must be done:

```
The error message when trying to open an executable file must:
- explain why this may be a dangerous file
- not give the option of launching it anyway 
```

So we just need a clear dialog titled __"THIS IS A PROGRAM"__ with a message along the lines of *"The file you are attempting to open is actually a program. Running programs from an untrusted source is dangerous, and can lead to data being deleted or your privacy being compromised."*.

Ubuntu's policy goes on to say that the message should `link to a web page that has more details`, but there is no reason that these details cannot be provided in the dialog itself. For example, *"If you trust this program and would like to run it, then you can do this by right-clicking on it and selecting "Run Program", or by giving it execute permission from the File Properties dialog"*. The words "File Properties" could be linked to the permissions tab of the File Properties dialog.

These actions (right-clicking or opening File Properties) require conscious effort on the part of the user, so there is no chance that the user will do them accidentally or automatically without understanding the significance.

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience

note.body:
Thanks for the input @mdz! So it looks like we might actually be able to reach a consensus here...

We have established that Ubuntu's policy was originally intended to prevent users running untrusted programs *accidentally* (i.e. when double-clicking or "opening" a program that lacks the executable bit), __but the policy was not intended to prevent users from running programs *intentionally*__.

That being the case, are there any remaining objections to @antoniof's [original proposal](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/443) of adding a "Run as Program" option to the right-click context menu that is available (with a warning message) even for files lacking the executable bit?

@antoniof's proposal covers the case where the user *knowingly* wants to __run__ a program. Are there any objections to [my proposal for a "THIS IS A PROGRAM" warning message (and instructions)](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/443#note_231683) when a user tries to __open__ (i.e. not necessarily run) a binary executable that lacks the executable bit?

events.target_title: Improve running binaries experience
Decide how to sensibly handle the execute bit (with regard to #443)

note.body:
This definitely affects #443, but I don't see it as a blocking issue. The executable bit has always been the sole indicator of trust on Unix systems, so it would be perfectly justifiable (and consistent with the security policy of all major distributions) for #443 to proceed as-is.

The question here is really about whether there needs to be a separate trust system on top of the executable bit. This applies not only to #433, but also to the general case of running a script, binary, or `.desktop` file from the file manager (the extra trust system will not affect files run from the terminal).

---

Regarding the proposed methods, I'm not keen on having separate metadata files scattered throughout the filesystem. I would prefer any metadata to be added to the file in question, or maintained in a per-user and/or per-system database. If using the database method, files should be identified via hashes rather than by name, preferably with hashes pre-calculated and cached to avoid delays when a user tries to run a program. [`inotify`](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inotify) could be used to detect when files are modified (or moved/renamed) and hashes need to be recalculated. Alternatively, `inotify` could be used to check for new files being created that have the executable bit set, and blacklisting those files until the user has expressly given permission for them to run.

However, my preferred option is actually not to introduce a new trust system and instead to modify File Roller to warn when extracting files that have the executable bit set.

events.target_title: First pass at improving reader mode styling

note.body:
The `line-height` property should nearly always use unitless values; that is, `line-height: 1.65` instead of `165%` or `1.65em`. Otherwise the line height will be wrong on elements that inherit the line height but have a different font size.

Also, 165% of the font size is probably too much unless the line length is very long or the font’s x-height is very high (Merriweather’s isn’t). It should be at most 145%.

events.target_title: Reader mode could use some typography love 💕

note.body:
> Using relative measures this ensures that zooming in the reading mode always results in a pleasant design, where proportions are kept.

There are good reasons to use length units relative to font size, but this isn’t one of them. The proportions are kept when zooming even if lengths are specified with `px`.

events.target_title: schemas: change default monospaced and document fonts

note.body:
For the UI font, I think a fallback can be defined at https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/5e96129be1698287a54ebadbcd0f5d08d219ff91/gtk/gtksettings.c#L449, which should presumably be changed to use the system UI generic family [once that's in fontconfig](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/fontconfig/fontconfig/merge_requests/20) to [prevent vertical overflow](https://github.com/googlei18n/noto-source/blob/master/FONT_CONTRIBUTION.md#document-vs-ui-fonts).

For the monospace font, in principle nothing needs to be done because applications should already fall back to the generic monospace family if Source Code Pro is not available.

However, Anjuta just [gets the monospace font from the setting](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/anjuta/blob/739551790cb3a10b19340ff2cd368b5c7cb3899b/plugins/sourceview/sourceview-prefs.c#L178-179) and [sets the font](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/anjuta/blob/fe71477aa77990669adfe672f6247b379b886f1c/plugins/sourceview/anjuta-view.c#L557-560) with that name. Therefore, if Source Code Pro is not available, it will not use a monospace font; this is not what was intended.

Sadly, there is an epidemic as this is likely to affect most applications using `pango_font_description_to_css` from libdazzle. For example, GNOME Logs [gets the font name from the setting](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-logs/blob/db78a3f67a615e2fab8faa36040ca31dd07e2229/src/gl-application.c#L47) and passes a font description to libdazzle to create the CSS fragment. Naturally, [libdazzle adds no generic family](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libdazzle/blob/d82bb6fc22708695626f2a76f915c2c534aa128c/src/util/dzl-pango.c#L51); and how would libdazzle know that you expect a monospace font anyway?

Interestingly, Looking Glass [sets no generic family](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/15e7625c80738906ec0770c337e5a86564987173/js/ui/lookingGlass.js#L899-907) either. So if you set the monospace font in GNOME Tweaks to some font, and uninstall that font, then after restarting the shell Looking Glass will use DejaVu Sans (or your generic sans-serif family) in the evaluator.

Thankfully, for the document font there really is nothing that needs to be fixed when Cantarell is not available.

events.target_title: Offering a non-developer friendly suggestion platform
Updating a Gnome extension automatically enables it
Offering a non-developer friendly suggestion platform

note.body:
@sri I think you exactly make my point … 

> Suggestions are fine but it needs to be within context of the direction that GNOME is going.

Which direction is that. If you receive "too many" suggestions which point into another direction, that might be very good indication that you are actually going in the wrong direction.

> So in general, having a suggestion box is fine as long as we have some control over the suggestions

Telling users what they should want is something different than to listen to what the users actually want.

I do think that with this behavior you are scaring people away over the long term and not create an open community.

Looking at the blog post a while back: https://feaneron.com/2018/04/20/the-infamous-gnome-shell-memory-leak/ (Section: Final Thoughts)

The question is raised:

> It almost feels like there’s a wall between the community and the users of what this community produces. Which is weird. We are an open community, with open development, no barriers for new contributors – and yet, there is such a distance between the community of users and the community of developers/designers/outreachers/etc.

Only accepting suggestions and listening to your users when it matches your perspective anyway exactly leads to that perception of Gnome I think.

events.target_title: Demand for more elaborate INSTALL instructions.

note.body:
@0x00111111 The way I went about building Gimp myself from source was to run:

$ sudo apt-get build-dep gimp

To install all dependencies for building the Ubuntu-shipped version of Gimp.

Then used:

$ ./configure --prefix=/home/<username>/dev/gimp

To make sure that my version didn't conflict with the Ubuntu version. The first few times, the configure script may moan about some libraries not being the correct versions, most notably GEGL & BABL. All I did in that case was to download the newer versions (source code, in my case) and installed those, and then re-ran the Gimp configure script.

I found that Ubuntu 18.04 ships the correct versions of most of the required libraries for Gimp 10, with GEGL & BABL being the exceptions. Meanwhile, Ubuntu 16 & 17 would require a little more work on your part, as some of their libraries aren't as up to date as required.

Hope that helps.

PhotonQyv (:*

NB. I configure both BABL & GEGL to install on top of the Ubuntu versions, just because it makes it easier, but if you don't set the prefix they'll be installed in /usr/local which keeps them out of the way. I've created a symbolic link in my $HOME/bin directory that points to the compiled Gimp app, but you could always just not set the --prefix option and then Gimp 10 would be /usr/local/bin/gimp-2.10

events.target_title: Demand for more elaborate INSTALL instructions.

note.body:
@0x00111111 Hi Z D (:*

[ How to install Gimp 2.10.4 on Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial Xerus): https://gitlab.gnome.org/snippets/189 ]


The first thing I'd suggest is that you download a more up to date version of Gimp, a 2.10 version, as that is the newest release version, rather than 2.9.8. Then you will also need to get newer versions of both GEGL & BABL since it looks like the ones you have are a little old (that error re: gegl_create_chain_argv is suggestive of this).

I have babl 0.1.55 & gegl 0.4.7, which enables me to build & install Gimp 2.10.5

$ pkg-config --modversion babl

Gives 0.1.55

$ pkg-config --modversion gegl-0.4

Gives 0.4.7

$ pkg-config --modversion gegl-0.3  (in your case will give you the version).

NOTE: gegl requires babl, so configure will moan if the version of babl is wrong, and then Gimp configure will moan if either babl OR gegl are the wrong versions.

If you use the same configure for each, i.e.

$ ./configure --prefix=/usr/local

Each configure script will be able to pick up the newer (correct) versions, and should compile, if there's anything seriously wrong the configure scripts will error and will tell you what you need to do, whether that be installing another library, or whatever.

After you build and install babl run:

$ pkg-config --modversion babl

And check that the version it returns is correct. Do the same when you've built and installed gegl, and again check that it shows the right version:

$ pkg-config --modversion gegl-0.4

Provided both return the right versions for what you've just built and installed, the Gimp configure script should not give any errors relating to them. NB. Gimp 2.10 needs gegl-0.4 rather than gegl-0.3.

Hope this is of help, let me know if you have any more trouble, and I'll try to give you some more pointers.

I'm a Gimp user, just like you, rather than one of the developers. I've just been building it a little longer than you have, perhaps (;*

PhotonQyv

events.target_title: Nautilus freezes with multiple disks setup with nested bind mounts

note.body:
You can find the mount situation in the example [fstab](/uploads/8e33e065fa9984a856a796d626708e25/fstab) attached. Browse with this mount scenario through different involved directories and after some seconds nautilus get stuck. The situation is not too bad, if you have only 4 or 5 disks involved (freezings below 3 seconds). But the more disks you have, the worse it gets. With 8 or more disks it's getting unsuable. All disks are internally connected via SATA.

Bind mounts are very good described on [https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/198590/what-is-a-bind-mount](https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/198590/what-is-a-bind-mount)

*A bind mount is an alternate view of a directory tree. Classically, mounting creates a view of a storage device as a directory tree. A bind mount instead takes an existing directory tree and replicates it under a different point. The directories and files in the bind mount are the same as the original. Any modification on one side is immediately reflected on the other side, since the two views show the same data.*

Mails that are not encrypted, look encrypted

note.body: BTW, you should also check for PLAINTEXT before BEGIN_DECRYPTION.

events.target_title: [GPG] Mails that are not encrypted look encrypted

note.body:
At the moment we don't know about a way to misuse this, so I am not filing it as a security vulnerability. Just a weird and potentially dangerous bug.
According to OpenPGP, the literal plaintext must be inside the encrypted data packet, otherwise it is not a single OpenPGP message (see message composition in the RFC). That's why strict checking should be safe. If there is no plaintext packet between BEGIN_ and END_DECRYPTION, you can assume NODATA and an appropriate error code, even if GnuPG reports a good encryption result.

events.target_title: [GPG] Mails that are not encrypted look encrypted

note.body: Another point of data: If the message is signed, then GnuPG will do proper validation. For example, a message that is only signed will have PLAINTEXT but no BEGIN_DECRYPTION, so that's a case where PLAINTEXT can legitimately occur outside BEGIN/END_DECRYPTION.

note.body: I will add that.

events.target_title: gtlscertificate: Add support for TPM keys in PEM files

note.body:
I'm using this together with glib-openssl. There are two engines for OpenSSL that enables support for using keys protected by TPM:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/jejb/openssl_tpm2_engine.git/

https://github.com/tpm2-software/tpm2-tss-engine

These is no code related TPM in the GTlsBackend, it is all handled by OpenSSL and its engines. This means that GTlsBackend or any upper layer should not try to interpret the PEM data, but instead just try to load it by passing it to the lower layer and see if there is an engine that supports it. The current parsing of the private key prevents this from happening, and that's what this patch solves. The two engines above both use the PEM guard added in this patch.

Another option would be to not parse for specific private key PEM guards, but instead do a more generic parsing to allow anything called "PRIVATE KEY", which would allow other type of keys to be supported by lower layers in the future without the need to change in gio. But that would also change current behavior of returning an error for e.g. "ENCRYPTED PRIVATE KEY", but maybe it actually makes sense that the lower layers decide this?

events.target_title: gtlscertificate: Add support for TPM keys in PEM files

note.body:
When looking at the documentation it's not obvious how this should be handled. GTlsCertificate specifies which key formats that are supported, but in the same time there is support for different GTlsBackend. Wouldn't it be more natural if it was GTlsBackend that decide on supported formats? How would you otherwise handle that different GTlsBackend support different key formats?

Maybe the documentation could reflect what the default GTlsBackend supports, and then this patch could just change the key parsing to allow any PEM with "PRIVATE KEY" which would allow GTlsBackend to support additional key formats?

events.target_title: LCH saturation change causes color shift
saturation change causes color shift (with default settings)

note.body:
Just from my side to confirm.

Of course, this is not a classic bug. We all are used to the saturation formulas of lch or hsl/hsv and so there is no surprise or serious problem.

I found this issue because of my maybe weird raw workflow, that requires desaturation for clipped colours. Because I'm limited to layer blend mode math, I looked for a method to desaturate. There I discovered the difference between the linear blending pixel / Y(pixel) and LCH Chroma reduction.
... further details should maybe not be part of this bug report.

I'm convinced, one has to be as close as possible to physics (scene referred image editing) to avoid unwanted side-effects and to increase robustness during image editing. That's why, I raised this issue, not primarily due to image quality problems. In fact, the latter is noticeable. 

**If our understanding of saturation in GIMP is, that mixing a colour and the fully desaturated colour in equal portions results in half saturation, then utilizing LCH chroma to desaturate is definitively the wrong (but widely accepted and established) concept.** This, I intended to illustrate with my pigments / raster 'simulation', that consists half/half of colour and fully desaturated colour.

The solution, that meets the above-mentioned understanding of saturation is this kind of linear blending between CIE Y and the original colour.

You are really fast by immediately creating and tuning a workshop op. :-)

Cheers,
Immanuel

events.target_title: saturation change causes color shift (with default settings)

note.body:
@ellestone I know about Abney. What I wanted to say with my reference to physics is, that one intuitively thinks, that "the truth" is represented by the dithered results.

The dithering method also shows the abney effect. It exactly meets the blending result (what surprise :-))

But, when we should choose a solution, that looks different from the dithered result, is the dithering operation still a valid option in general? Your RT LAB result - does it correspond to the dithered one?

Cheers,
Immanuel

events.target_title: saturation change causes color shift (with default settings)

note.body:
With dithering I mean, a composition of two (or more) components (infinitesimal small) to simulate a 3rd color. 
Like a checkerboard from far far away. It appears grey while none of the compontents (black white) is grey. A one by one mixture of black and white.
How would the checkerboard of a color and its desaturated pendant look? This might be the intuitively right solution. :-)
What is desaturation? Is it a piecewise, incremental mixing of a color with her desaturated pendant?
Like mixing two powders. One powder with multispectral grey and one with the monochromatic color.

The CIECAM results look closest to what is expected. I think. But I don't know, whether this is "only" psychological, because I'm used to this expectations without knowing why... Or for what premises of the appearance model this expectation is valid.

OK; I see: Obviously I had always been selecting another tool after Color->Curves, so I never noticed how it works.
However, I think the user interfaces is really broken regarding this:

1. How is the user expected to cancel the tool (in addition to pressing "Cancel" in the dialogue)?

note.body:
I've tested this in Firefox 60 and Opera 53 as well.

Firefox has ad blocking via ublock-origin and Opera has the built-in ad blocker (which uses Easylist, EasyPrivacy, and NoCoin). Loading and scrolling BGR articles works fine in those browsers.

I know that some websites deploy honeypots to try to detect ad blockers, but ad blocking rule sets like Easylist try to work around this, and ublock-origin goes even further by disarming certain Javascript programs and/or substituting them with its own version.

events.target_title: GDK does not respect XDG_SESSION_TYPE - causing issues

note.body:
@matthiasc How is looking at `WAYLAND_DISPLAY` worse? In what way would it break wayland sessions? And how do you plan to solve this if not by environment variables?

I'm asking because I'm looking at the same issue for Qt and was considering to go in the opposite direction and start to look at both, i.e. here's what I was thinking:

- If `QT_QPA_PLATFORM` (i.e. `GDK_BACKEND`) is set, just use that
- Otherwise, use `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` if set
- Otherwise, use wayland if `WAYLAND_DISPLAY` is set

In the last two cases, add xcb as a fallback in case connecting fails or no suitable shell extension is found.

Would perhaps be a little bit confusing for people running a wayland compositor nested inside an X session, as they would need to set or unset `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` manually or use `QT_QPA_PLATFORM` to start applications inside the nested compositor.

note.body: See `openconnect_drop_child_privs()`. We already drop root privs and run as an unprivileged `nm-openconnect` user. I'm surprised that passing `--csd-user 0` actually worked; surely you need to use gl.tun_owner instead?

events.target_title: service: include --csd-wrapper script in openconnect arguments

note.body: Ah, except Dan you didn't actually make the GPST invocation of csd_wrapper honour csd_user at all, did you? :)

events.target_title: service: include --csd-wrapper script in openconnect arguments

note.body: Ok, so this patch should simply provide the user that openconnect is going to be invoked as, and we should be fine.

events.target_title: service: include --csd-wrapper script in openconnect arguments

note.body:
You're still running as root at this point. Otherwise the call to `create_persistent_tundev()` just below isn't going to work... 

Privs get dropped later, actually within the `openconnect_drop_child_privs()` call from `g_spawn_async_with_pipes()`. So instead of `getuid()` here you want `gl.tun_owner`.

note.body:

events.target_title: Sidebar + hierarchical tags-based workflow

note.body:
This is exactly what I need at the present. The way I see it, tag based filtering can do everything a list can do plus way way more. The list system could even be removed completely, leaving behind only the storage location of each task. The idea of lists I believe (correct me if I'm wrong) is to cleanly separate tasks and prevent confusion, like you wouldn't want work to be mixing with personal things. But tags can do that. Not to mention, tags are not mutually exclusive (one task can have multiple tags) and it is very easy for tasks to switch from using one tag to another (unlike lists which tasks cannot be transferred between, as far as i can see)

In summary, tags seems to be the simplest and most flexible way of organizing tasks, since organization of tasks is completely left up to the user. And if hierarchical tags could be implemented, then it would be perfect.

Please, please please consider this. I can create some mockup GUIs in Glade for design considerations

Map-Displace Filter parameters not retained for Repeat functionality

note.body:
No, none of the parameters are retained after applying filter, map, displace on a layer. Doing a control-F / repeat filter achieves nothing as the values are all reset to default or 'do nothing' values.

The horizontal and vertical displacements are stored and can be recovered, by using the presets drop down. The AUX1 setting is not included with the preset values.

note.body:
>A few years ago there was a so-called "cybersecurity" bill that could have been argued to outlaw open source software. It didn't pass congress but who knows whether that would be enforced.

Could you tell what bill you mean? I'm not a US resident and have not heard about it.

>Hello, the reason is to prevent spam, it works. Do you have any suggestion for a different technology similar to ReCaptcha?

If you really want captcha, recaptcha is out of competition: since Google is the leading AI company to beat ReCaptcha one has to beat Google neural network using bunches of proprietary custom-made trade secret TPUs unavailable to anyone else, but once he done that, he can do more profitable business than breaking captchas. Anyway, every succesfully solved captcha makes Google recaptcha stronger. And since Google is a leading tracking company, beating their image recognition will be not enough.

I don't know what to do. But recaptcha is completely inacceptable. Type text captchas are too dumb and are easyly broken. You can design a custom captcha not worth an effort to break, like this one: ![](https://lurkmore.to/images/7/71/%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BF%D1%87%D0%B01.png). The captcha like described can be used not only to keep away spammers, but also mentally weak people.

Maybe throw away captcha completely and act retroactively: classify each message with xgboost into either spam or not spam and make a human to decide.


Another solution is proof-of-work. And use the money from mining to fund moderation team. I mean a spammer will have to provide a pow which will be used to delete his messages. But a benign user will have to provide PoW rarely to keep the resource clean from spammers for its own convenience. It's quite fair assumming that moderations are legit, so we need a mechanism to remove moderators. But please, don't use Coinhive, setup an own one using WebAssembly.

events.target_title: service: include --csd-wrapper script in openconnect arguments

note.body:
An issue I had when I tried to (ab)use the Secrets API for non-secrets (or temporary ones like the OpenVPN dynamic challenge) was that the new secret ('x-openconnect-csd',...) doesn't have any flags and so NM saves its value as returned by agents in the connection the first time. The next time the plugin asks it, NM will return it from the connection instead of querying the agent.

I thought about introducing a special prefix for such secrets to avoid them being saved, see:

https://cgit.freedesktop.org/NetworkManager/NetworkManager/commit/?h=bg/vpn-ask-username-rh1535517&id=9d15705a6abac2047f1adce4212beb8ce4a7c119

But in the end, I think it would be better if we extend the Secrets API instead.

events.target_title: Redesign the main user experience

note.body:
Hey @feaneron It is looking good!

**Sub-tasks**
I agree with the management of sub-tasks, one question, If I check the main task as done, that means all my sub-task will be checked as done?

**Search**
The search needs to "search" within the context, if you carry the category label next to it user expectations are to search for that specific category

**New task row**
The reason I like the proposed new task row is that in the case of having a long list of tasks your **primary** action doesn't get hidden at the bottom, you always have the chance to add a new task no matter how long your list is.

**Color strip**
I will vote for the strip :slight\_smile: this gives a perfect clue about the list your looking at without interfering with the readability of the list and preventing visual fatigue. Another advantage is that users can choose whatever colour they want. If we go for the gradient, this can introduce readability issues, and there will be parts where it will be easier to read and some parts harder.


@mykola.kb the idea behind folders is to help you organize things that make sense together. I think will depend on how people use it, I agree that each list can be seen as a project and from there will be easier to help you complete things. But let's say if the main group "this computer" groups all your lists/projects how can you differenciate the list that belongs to a home project to a work project to a family project, it can get difficult to manage all of them more if the lists are sorted alphabetically.


Let me know what do you think

events.target_title: Moving the network panel up to wireless/bluetooth

note.body:
Network settings needs to be on the same group, I did some work on how to re-group the options

This includes
* Airplane mode
* Wifi
* Ethernet
* Bluetooth

**Airplane mode**

Context: this option is located on the bluetooth settings, and the top toggle control is not used to switch it on or off so it gets confusing, you need to "disable" airplane mode in the panel area.

**Suggestions:**

* Move everything related to network into one single section called "Network" so you can manage your connections from there.
* Include airplane mode here because this option impacts mainly network connections

![network_-_airplane_on](/uploads/a5c2fe76285b1eea5ad90c409c8d5de6/network_-_airplane_on.png)

**Wifi**

* Show additional information to active connections, IP and Wifi name
* Show if wifi network is off or disconnected
![network_-_wifi_connected](/uploads/2f020e6c7eaa85246939b3366fa1dbb0/network_-_wifi_connected.png)
![network_-_wifi_disconnected](/uploads/87b5a19cac27582f3ae0f8ac9205a7bd/network_-_wifi_disconnected.png)
![network_-_wifi_off](/uploads/a84320f502feaeeee3ac24778389a091/network_-_wifi_off.png)

* Show wifi list on range on a separated panel, following additional settings interactions.

![network_-_wifi_settings](/uploads/31930bc985d58d628324c2da6c314c50/network_-_wifi_settings.png)


** Bluetooth **

* Keep only the option to enable or disable the bluetooth

![bluetooth_off](/uploads/399e354fa029946aeacea492c2728eb5/bluetooth_off.png)
![bluetooth_on](/uploads/b5accff6531344db3b34afc662ca8d3b/bluetooth_on.png)

![bluetooth_off__airplane_on_](/uploads/5dbdea844a5f7c297801a7e56b21ed60/bluetooth_off__airplane_on_.png)

events.target_title: [Texttool] Support for East Asian vertical text writing style

note.body:
> what are the rules to mix rtl/ltr and ttb text? 

In W3C document [Requirements for Japanese Text Layout](https://w3c.github.io/jlreq/#mixed_text_composition_in_vertical_writing_mode), section 3.2.3 and 3.2.4 having some rules for texts that mixed horizontal and vertical direction.

> Should we allow any script to be ttb-able or only the ones from language allowing it? 

We should allow any script to work with TTB direction. See the Unicode Technical Note No.22 at above.
